newsitem.title: USA: Distant "blobs" may be building blocks of galaxies.
newsitem.headline: Distant "blobs" may be building blocks of galaxies.

text.p: Astronomers said on Wednesday they had identified "blobs" in the distant sky that they believed were the basic building blocks of galaxies.
"There are 18 little blobs, 11 billion light years from Earth," seen through the Hubble Space Telescope, astronomer Rogier Windhorst told a NASA news briefing in Washington.

The theory is that "subgalactic clumps" like these would eventually have merged and "grown into the galaxies we see around us," added Windhorst, a professor at Arizona State University at Tempe and the co-author of an article about the findings in Thursday's edition of the journal Nature.
In a galaxy, such as the Milky Way, billions of stars are bound together by gravity. Galaxies are the largest assemblages of stars in the universe.
Astronomers had long sought galactic building blocks, but no land-based telescope had the power to detect them.
The Hubble was able to see them near the constellation Hercules, 11 billion light years away, in a glimpse of the era during which galaxies are commonly believed to have formed.
"This is the first page of an otherwise blank book," Bruce Margon, an astronomer at the University of Washington at Seattle, told the National Aeronautics and Space Administration briefing.
Each blob has about a billion young stars.
Astronomers have already seen stars form. "Stars form all the time. It's a continual process of birth, maturation, death," Margon said. "Galaxies do not form all the time."
Although Windhorst said he believed his blobs would collide and merge into bigger galaxies, some astronomers hold rival theories.
Anne Kinney, an astronomer at the Space Telescope Science Institute, said there was still no proof whether galaxies "form from small to big or big to small."
